title: Is it possible to go from a 3.8 weighted GPA to a 4.2 weighted GPA in one year with 6 AP classes? - Quora
tags: Grade Point Average and University Admissions

response.answer_text: It depends on the weighting. The question is just why anybody would take 6 AP courses—or any. The AP program was set up by the College Board when they realized that their PSAT and SAT had market saturation. They weren’t going to make much more money with those tests. Offering college credit for courses taken in high school if students passed tests on those courses sounded like a great deal, especially to parents who got both bragging rights and reduction of tuition costs. Colleges, however, have realized that AP courses are a scam. The curriculum isn’t college level and neither is the teaching. Few college courses use multiple choice final examinations. As a result, more and more colleges each year refuse to accept the “college” credit from AP. Here it is, from a college professor who has watched this transpire over the last thirty years. If you want college credit, get it through dual enrollment at your local community college. The credits are more likely to transfer and you’ll have earned them in a real college classroom. And I’ll tell you what I tell my students: “If GPA truly matters to you, it matters to you on the first day of class, not halfway through the course.”
A2A, I would expect a junior to do how to calculate a maximum GPA where the top school is 4.2. It would be (2+3.8+1*4.2)/3=3.93.
